crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects suspicious single byte XORed keyword 'Mozilla/5.0' - it uses yara's XOR modifier and therefore cannot print the XOR key. You can use the CyberChef recipe linked in the reference field to brute force the used key.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth

attributes.magic: ELF 32-bit LSB executable, Renesas SH, version 1 (SYSV), statically linked, stripped

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis: This RISC-V ELF binary is identified as an IoT botnet agent, likely a variant of Mirai or Gafgyt, specialized for Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. Key indicators include the presence of strings associated with Layer 7 HTTP attacks, specifically targeting the '/cdn-cgi/' path (a known technique for attempting to bypass Cloudflare protection) and the use of custom 'User-Agent' headers. The binary is statically linked and lacks external library imports, which is a common characteristic of malware designed for deployment across diverse embedded Linux environments.
